data.title: SFTP & SSH Remote Projects Support
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.9.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 Pro

Is it possible to embed a good sftp tool to manage remote projects?
There is an extension for doing just that but it has some bugs and an official-maintained plugin would be a million times better!

data.title: Auto save onEditorFocusLost should only save when focus leaves the editor
data.body:
Steps to Reproduce:

1. enable `autoSave: onEditorFocusLost`
2. make a file dirty
3. bring up the find widget

=> the editor is saved

We have seen numerous issues doing so (https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/20989, https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/16659) so the change is to only trigger auto save when the editor actually looses focus, but not when you click to any other widget within the editor.

data.title: Make command palette remember the last command
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.9
- OS Version: Linux

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Press Ctrl + Shift + P to open command palette.
2. Enter some command eg. _Toggle Activity Bar visiblity_
3. Now again open command palette -> last entered command is not remembered.

Sublime text has this very useful feature, would love to see in VSCode too.

data.title: Wrapping settings are confusing
data.body: ## The problem There are two important settings in VS Code that control line wrapping. * `editor.wrappingColumn` (300 by default) * and `editor.wordWrap` (false by default) Examples (with explanations): | `wordWrap` | `wrappingColumn` | Behaviour | |---|---|---| | false | N > 0 | Lines will wrap at N | | false | 0 | Lines will wrap at viewport_column | | false | -1 | Lines will never wrap. | | true | N > 0 | Lines will wrap at min(viewport_column, N) | | true | 0 | Lines will wrap at viewport_column | | true | -1 | Lines will never wrap. | The fact that `wrappingColumn` is the primary setting and that we wrap at 300 by default is causing a lot of pain. For example, the Toggle Word Wrap action toggles `wordWrap: false | true` in user settings. But if `wrappingColumn` is also configured, the action becomes a no-op. --- ## The proposal The proposal is to focus on the most important use-cases and to make `wordWrap` the **primary** setting. To prevent unexpected behaviours for folks already using `wrappingColumn`, it will be completely ignored (deprecated) and a new setting `editor.wordWrapColumn` will take part of its attributes: | `editor.wordWrap` | Behaviour | |---|---| | "off" | Lines will never wrap. | | "on" | Lines will wrap at viewport | | "wordWrapColumn" | Lines will wrap at editor.wordWrapColumn | | "bounded" | Lines will wrap at min(viewport, editor.wordWrapColumn) | The defaults **change to** => `wordWrap: "off"`, `wordWrapColumn: 80` The Toggle Word Wrap action should toggle `wordWrap: "on" | "off"` in user settings. There is a separate issue #20675, tracking that the Toggle Word Wrap should not persist to user settings or do so in a per-buffer way.

data.title: smartStep/SkipFiles and stopOnEntry=true should stop at first actual source line mapped
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.9.1
- OS Version: OS X

VSCode fails to stop at first mapped line of source code encountered inside a project when smartStep/SkipFiles is specified.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. For a nodejs project, add debug launch task for node/node2 and mocha tests, specify smartStep and/or skipFiles so mocha's own source code is not being debugged and specify stopOnEntry=true as shown in the example launch.json file below:
2. Run debugger
3. Note that the debugger breaks at the wrong place and fail to show an active source file.  

Expected behaviour:
The debugger should break at the first available source file inside the project that is both mapped and is not covered by the skipFiles paths.

**Example launch.json**
```
{
    "version": "0.2.0",
    "configurations": [

        {
            "type": "node2",
            "request": "launch",
            "name": "Mocha Tests",
            "cwd": "${workspaceRoot}",
            "runtimeExecutable": "${workspaceRoot}/node_modules/.bin/mocha",
            "windows": {
                "runtimeExecutable": "${workspaceRoot}/node_modules/.bin/mocha.cmd"
            },
            "runtimeArgs": [
                "-u",
                "bdd",
                "--timeout",
                "999999",
                "--colors",
                "${workspaceRoot}/dist/spec/**/*.spec.js"
            ],
            "internalConsoleOptions": "openOnSessionStart",
            "stopOnEntry": true,
            "smartStep": true,
            "skipFiles": [
			    "${workspaceRoot}/node_modules/**/'.js"
		    ]
        }
    ]
}
```

data.title: CodeLens doesn't work for folded lines when switch back to original file
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.9.1
- OS Version: macOS

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Enable the Typescript CodeLens: `"typescript.referencesCodeLens.enabled": true`.
2. Open a TypeScript file, after some time (very short), the references count will be display above the lines of methods and classes.
3. Fold the class code, switch to another tab in VSCode, and then switch back to original file.
4. Unfold the class in the file, no CodeLens above the method signature lines are shown(Here for line 8, 51 and 55).

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2796177/23252055/63a4c1aa-f9ea-11e6-88d0-46a7ae4a105f.png)

data.title: Improve guidance when attaching through legacy launch config to node > v6.9
data.body:
Testing #20779

- node v6.9.4 installed
- create a launch config 'Node.js: Attach (Legacy Protocol)'

As expected this doesn't work and I get the error: 
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/172399/23249897/e2765564-f9a6-11e6-8d35-24d6a383174a.png)

Suggest that when an attach is done using the legacy protocol and the attach fails, then the message mentions that attach should be tried using the 'inspector' protocol.

data.title: Add Opacity-Setting to Minimap
data.body:
There is no visual difference between the editor background and the minimap background. If you've one single long line in your code (and we all have those 80+ char lines :stuck_out_tongue_winking_eye:) the minimap cuts of the last characters and you don't realy realise it. 
### Minimap On:
![grafik](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3358663/23249323/03cba456-f9a4-11e6-84db-4236456c94c0.png)
### Minimap Off:
![grafik](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3358663/23249337/1eb48f94-f9a4-11e6-9263-18142454404d.png)

I suggest a `editor.minimap.opacity` User Settings to add CSS Opacity to the Minimap.
### Minimap with Opacity `0.6`:
![grafik](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3358663/23249421/951fb03c-f9a4-11e6-8153-332b55169808.png)

data.title: Keep Side Bar position per window
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.9.1
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.3

Steps to Reproduce:

1. View - Move Side Bar Right
2. Open new window, name it `window:2`
3. View - Move Side Bar Left on `window:2`
4. Position of Side Bar on the first window changed by step 3.

`Toggle Side Bar` action does work per window as I favor, and I think most of people would expect so.
